facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 354 of 1957 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 7, 1955, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 422 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 354 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 7, 1955, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 422 of 1954.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on September 22, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. September 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This appeal by the State of Bihar challenges the companyrectness of an order made by the High Court at Patna in an application by the respondent under Art. 226 of the companystitution.

facts.text: The respondent was inducted as a tenant on a tract of land measuring 245.69 acres in village Singpur by the then proprietor in November 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was inducted as a tenant oil a tract of land measuring 245.69 acres in village Singpur by the then proprietor in November 1945, and companytinued to remain in possession after the Zemindari interest of the proprietor became vested in the State of Bihar in companysequence of a numberification under the Bihar Land Reforms Act  Bihar Act XXX of 1952  on the 30th December, 1952.

facts.text: The respondent continued to remain in possession after the Zemindari interest vested in the State of Bihar on December 30, 1952 under Bihar Land Reforms Act XXX of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and companytinued to remain in possession after the Zemindari interest of the proprietor became vested in the State of Bihar in companysequence of a numberification under the Bihar Land Reforms Act  Bihar Act XXX of 1952  on the 30th December, 1952.

facts.text: In 1945 this area was forest land.

anchor.surface_text: In 1945 this area was forest land. On September 15, 1946, a numberification was published under section 14 of the Bihar Private Forest Act, 1946 declaring the Governments intention of companystituting the forest a private protected forest.

facts.text: On September 15, 1946, a notification was published under section 14 of the Bihar Private Forest Act, 1946 declaring the Government's intention of constituting the forest a private protected forest.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1946, a numberification was published under section 14 of the Bihar Private Forest Act, 1946 declaring the Governments intention of companystituting the forest a private protected forest. By the same numberification the Governor further ordered that until the publication of a numberification under a. 30 of the Act all the rights to out, companylect and remove trees or any class of trees in or from the forest shall cease to exist subject to companyditions and specifications specified in the Second Schedule.

facts.text: Immediately on publication of the September 15, 1946 notification, the respondent's right to cut, collect and remove trees ceased so long as this forest continued to be a private forest.

anchor.surface_text: The result of this numberification was that immediately on its publication in the Government Gazette the respondents right to cut, companylect and remove trees ceased so long as this forest companytinued to be a private forest.

facts.text: On April 6, 1948, a notification under the proviso to section 30 of the Bihar Private Forest Act was published.

anchor.surface_text: On the 6th April, 1948, a numberification under the proviso to s. 30 of the Bihar Private Forest Act, was published.

facts.text: After vesting on December 30, 1952, a notification on January 22, 1953 was published, which both parties agree was in substance under the proviso to section 29 of the Indian Forest Act, 1927, making the forests in Singpur Village a protected forest.

anchor.surface_text: After the forest land became vested in the State on the 30th December, 1952, there was a numberification on January 22, 1953, which both parties agree, was in substance under the proviso to s. 29 of the Indian Forest Act, 1927. It is the companymon case of both the parties that in companysequence of this numberification the forests in Singpur Village became a protected forest.

facts.text: On May 29, 1953, a notification under section 30 of the Indian Forest Act prohibited breaking up or clearing the land of this and certain other protected forests for cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: On May 29, 1953, a further numberification under section 30 of, the Indian Forest Act was made prohibiting the breaking up or clearing the ,land of this and certain other protected forests for cultivation.

facts.text: Local employees of the Forest Department acting under the Divisional Forest Officer, Gaya, started interfering with the agricultural operations carried on behalf of the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: As local employees of the Forest Department acting under the Divisional Forest Officer, Gaya, started interfering with the agricultural operations carried on behalf of the petitioner apparently on the strength of this numberification of May 29, 1953, the respondent sought the per- mission of the Collector of Gaya to start reclamation and cultivation of lands.

facts.text: On April 22, 1954, the Collector of Gaya gave the petitioner permission to go ahead with reclamation and cultivation in this area.

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1954 the Collector of Gaya gave the petitioner permission to go ahead with the work of reclamation and cultivation in this area.

facts.text: The Forest Officer disregarded the Collector's orders and made the petitioner stop reclamation.

anchor.surface_text: The Forest Officer however disregarded the Collector orders and made the petitioner to stop reclamation.

facts.text: On June 10, 1954, the Bihar Government sent a telegram to the Collector, Gaya, desiring that the order issued by the Collector on April 22 permitting reclamation be withdrawn pending decision.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the Bihar Government sent a telegram to the Collector, Gaya, on June 10, 1954 desiring that the order issued by the Collector on April 22, permitting the respondent to go ahead with the reclamation should be withdrawn pending the decision of the Government in the matter.

facts.text: On June 11, 1954, the Collector forwarded a copy of the telegram to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector forwarded a companyy of this telegram to the respondent for information and necessary action on June 11, 1954.

facts.text: No further order has been made by Government in the matter.

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear that any further order has been made by Government in the matter.

facts.text: On August 2, 1954, the respondent made an application to the High Court of Judicature at Patna for a writ to cancel the directions of June 10, 1954 and restrain interference with possession over the land in Singpur.

anchor.surface_text: On August 2, 1954 the respondent made his application to the High Court of Judicature at Patna praying that an appropriate writ be issued for cancellation by the Government of Bihar of the directions given on June 10, 1954 to the Collector and for restraining the Government of Bihar and the Forest Officer from interfering with the petitioners possession over this land in village Singpur.

facts.text: The High Court allowed the petition, quashed the State Government's order of June 10 and the Forest Officer's order dated 1st May prohibiting reclamation.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the High Court allowed the petition and made an order quashing the State Governments order companyveyed in their telegram of the 10th June and the order of the Forest Officer dated the let May, by which this Officer had prohibited reclamation of the disputed land by the petitioner.

facts.text: Both parties agree that the notification of January 22, 1953 made the forests in Singpur Village a protected forest.

anchor.surface_text: It is the companymon case of both the parties that in companysequence of this numberification the forests in Singpur Village became a protected forest.

facts.text: The State contended that the petitioner's right to the land was extinguished under section 19 of Bihar Act IX of 1948 on publication of notification under proviso to section 30.

anchor.surface_text: In opposing the petition the State of Bihar companytended that the Collectors order was of numberavail in the face of rule 4 of the rules made by the Government of Bihar under section 32 which provides that numberperson shall out, companyvert, or remove from the said forest or otherwise deal in trees etc., of the forest except in accordance with Rules I, II and III.

facts.text: The High Court rejected the argument that rights were extinguished under section 19 as no final notification under section 30 was published.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this argu- ment, being of the opinion that extinction companyld take place only when the final numberification under section 30 was published and as this final numberification was number published section 19 had numberapplication to the case.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the Collector's permission under Rule 8 was valid and Forest Officer and Government had no authority to interfere.

anchor.surface_text: The permission given in the present case by the Collector was therefore in accordance with law and neither the Forest Officer number the Government had any authority in law to interfere with that permission.

facts.text: The Supreme Court modified the High Court order to issue a writ in the nature of mandamus instead of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that through some oversight the High Court ordered the issue of a writ of certiorari, though a writ in the nature of mandamus was prayed for. It is clear that the appropriate writ in the circumstances of the present case is a writ in the nature of mandamus and we modify the order made by the High Court to this extent that a writ in the nature of mandamus be issued directing the appellant-Government to cancel its order on the Collector made on June 10, 1954

holdings.text: The extinction of rights under s. 19 can take place only after the final notification under s. 30 has been published.

anchor.surface_text: All this clearly shows that the extinction of rights under s. 19 can take place only after the final notification under s. 30 has been published. It is necessary to consider next the apparent conflict between the powers of the Officers of the Forest Department under rr. 1 to 4 and the powers of the Collector under r. 8 of the Protected Forest Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.30 is interim pending claims under s.16, enquiry s.17, appeals s.27; final constitution only after process completion; s.19 extinction ties to final s.30 notification.

holdings.text: Rules 1 to 4 apply to cutting or removal of trees where the forest would continue to be a forest but cutting necessary for clearing land for cultivation is controlled only by Rule 8.

anchor.surface_text: The reasonable way of reading Rules 1 to 4 and Rule 8 appears to us to be that Rules 1 to 4 apply to the cutting or removal of trees where in spite of such cutting the forest would continue to be a forest but cutting of trees which is necessary for clearing the land for cultivation or any other purpose is not controlled by Rules 1, 2, 3 or 4 but only by Rule 8.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of rules under s.32: rr.1-4 under clauses a-d for selective cutting; r.8 under clause g for clearing land; pregnant negative in r.8 implies authority for cutting/removal.

holdings.text: The permission given by the Collector under Rule 8 was in accordance with law and neither the Forest Officer nor the Government had any authority in law to interfere with that permission.

anchor.surface_text: The permission given in the present case by the Collector was therefore in accordance with law and neither the Forest Officer nor the Government had any authority in law to interfere with that permission. The last argument advanced by Mr. Jha is that the prohibition by the State Government of clearing or breaking up for cultivation or for any other purpose of any land in a protected forest by the notification dated May 29, 1953,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of harmonious construction to facts; Collector's permission under r.8 valid for reclamation/cultivation involving tree cutting.

holdings.text: The prohibition by notification under s.30 is ineffective where clearing is done in accordance with Rule 8 made under s.32.

anchor.surface_text: All doubts are however set at rest by section 34 of the Act which runs thus - Nothing in this Chapter shall be deemed to prohibit any act done with the permission in writing of the Forest Officer, or in accordance with rules made under s. 32, or except as regards any portion of a forest closed under s. 30, or as regards any rights the exercise of which has been suspended under s. 33, in the exercise of any right recorded under section 29.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.34 expressly saves acts in accordance with rules under s.32 from prohibitions in Chapter IV including s.30 notifications.

holdings.text: There is no legal authority for the State Government to interfere with the clearing or cultivation of land by the respondent in accordance with the written permission granted by the Collector under Rule 8.

anchor.surface_text: All the contentions raised in the appeal therefore fail. We are of opinion that there is no legal authority for the State Government to interfere with the clearing or cultivation of land by the respondent which is proposed to be done in accordance with the written permission granted by the Collector under Rule 8 of the Protected Forest Rules, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts; appeal fails.

holdings.text: The appropriate writ is mandamus, not certiorari; High Court order modified accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that through some oversight the High Court ordered the issue of a writ of certiorari, though a writ in the nature of mandamus was prayed for. It is clear that the appropriate writ in the circumstances of the present case is a writ in the nature of mandamus and we modify the order made by the High Court to this extent that a writ in the nature of mandamus be issued directing the appellant-Government to cancel its order on the Collector made on June 10, 1954

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandamus prayed for and appropriate to direct cancellation and restraint; certiorari oversight.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the appropriate writ in the circumstances of the present case is a writ in the nature of mandamus and we modify the order made by the High Court to this extent that a writ in the nature of mandamus be issued directing the appellant-Government to cancel its order on the Collector made on June 10, 1954

restraining the Government and the Forest Officer from interfering with the petitioners possession over 245.69 acres of land in village Singpur

anchor.surface_text: All this clearly shows that the extinction of rights under s. 19 can take place only after the final notification under s. 30 has been published. anchor.surface_text: The reasonable way of reading Rules 1 to 4 and Rule 8 appears to us to be that Rules 1 to 4 apply to the cutting or removal of trees where in spite of such cutting the forest would continue to be a forest but cutting of trees which is necessary for clearing the land for cultivation or any other purpose is not controlled by Rules 1, 2, 3 or 4 but only by Rule 8.

It is clear that the appropriate writ in the circumstances of the present case is a writ in the nature of mandamus and we modify the order made by the High Court to this extent that a writ in the nature of mandamus be issued directing the appellant-Government to cancel its order on the Collector made on June 10, 1954

anchor.surface_text: The permission given in the present case by the Collector was therefore in accordance with law and neither the Forest Officer nor the Government had any authority in law to interfere with that permission. anchor.surface_text: All doubts are however set at rest by section 34 of the Act which runs thus - Nothing in this Chapter shall be deemed to prohibit any act done with the permission in writing of the Forest Officer, or in accordance with rules made under s. 32, or except as regards any portion of a forest closed under s. 30, or as regards any rights the exercise of which has been suspended under s. 33, in the exercise of any right recorded under section 29.
